factsheet.heading: History of Holy Trinity Church Bow
paragraphs: After decades of closure, falling into disrepair and undergoing extensive restoration work, Holy Trinity Church in Bow West is now fully watertight and ready for use.
Proposals for roof repairs were drawn up in 1989 by Keith Harrison and Associates, supported by Epainos Ministry and carried out with Heritage Lottery Funding in 1998-2000.

Holy Trinity Bow is a magnificent Grade C listed Church built between 1834 and 1841 to designs by Daniel and James Austin, local surveyors. It lies within the Tredegar Square Conservation Area on a site given by the developer of Tredegar Square, Sir Charles Morgan, and is surrounded by an unused churchyard, interesting monuments and gravestones

factsheet.heading: Current Update of the Heritage & Arts Centre Bow
paragraphs: Supported by the Heritage Lottery Fund it was reopened in 2019 and renamed The Heritage & Arts Centre Bow.

There are outstanding restoration work which have yet to be completed including restoring the door surround ie repairs & shelter coating to colonnettes; replacing the steps to the West entrance; removing vegetation growing adjacent to the Church; purchasing a portable wheelchair ramp with handrails and organising weekly site tours for local schools, universities, community and business associations. ( Please visit our Spacehive crowdfunding application for more information: https://www.spacehive.com/restoring-the-hac-bow-to-use )

factsheet.heading: Future Plans for The HAC Bow
paragraphs: We plan to continue restoring Holy Trinity Church Bow, now renamed The Heritage & Arts Centre (The HAC Bow), to provide improved access to an affordable, multi-purpose community space and garden from which a cross range of arts, music and heritage learning programmes, exhibitions and events can be offered.
